firstTime.scenario: I could use some advice here, friend. Got myself a nice piece of grilled trout with almonds and butter. Pretty straightforward dish, but I want to pick the right wine. What's your recommendation?

option1Wine.feedbackText: I see your thinking with a lighter red, but trout is delicate enough that even Pinot Noir might overpower it. Fish this delicate needs white wine's cleaner profile.

option2Wine.feedbackText: Solid choice! Chardonnay's got the body to handle the almonds and butter while its acidity keeps the pairing bright. Good match for the trout's delicate flavor.

option3Wine.feedbackText: Way too heavy there, buddy. Cabernet would completely steamroll over that trout. When you've got delicate fish, you need a wine that won't compete.

firstTime.scenario: I'm looking at this grilled pork chop with apple chutney on my plate. Seems like it could go either way with wine - I'm honestly not sure. Could you point me in the right direction?

option1Wine.feedbackText: Smart thinking! Riesling's touch of sweetness plays beautifully with that apple chutney, while its acidity cuts through the pork fat. Good call on matching the fruit flavors.

option2Wine.feedbackText: Not bad with the pork, but Cabernet might be too bold for the apple chutney. The fruit in the dish is calling for something with more finesse.

option3Wine.feedbackText: Could work with the pork, but you're missing the apple component. The chutney's sweetness needs a wine that can complement those fruit flavors.

firstTime.scenario: Got a hearty beef stew here - potatoes, carrots, rich gravy, the whole nine yards. Comfort food at its finest. What wine would you pair with something this substantial?

option1Wine.feedbackText: That's not gonna cut it, friend. Beef stew is too rich and hearty for Sauvignon Blanc. You need something with more body and tannins to stand up to all that richness.

option2Wine.feedbackText: Too light for the job. Beef stew needs a wine that can match its intensity. Riesling would get completely overwhelmed by all those hearty flavors.

option3Wine.feedbackText: Perfect match! Merlot's got the body to complement the beef and the tannins to cut through that rich gravy. Hearty food needs a hearty wine - you nailed it.

remedial.scenario: Let's try this again. I've got pan-seared scallops with a light cream sauce. Simple preparation, but I want to get the wine right this time. What do you think?

option1Wine.feedbackText: There you go! Chardonnay's richness matches that cream sauce while its acidity balances the scallops' sweetness. You're getting the hang of this!

option2Wine.feedbackText: Remember what we learned - delicate seafood needs delicate wine. Even light red wine can overpower scallops. Stick with whites for shellfish.

remedial.scenario: One more shot at this. I've got a thick ribeye steak, grilled medium-rare. Classic steakhouse preparation. I want to show I understand how to match wine intensity. Help me out?

option1Wine.feedbackText: Come on now, you know better! Ribeye is rich and fatty - it needs a wine with tannins and body to cut through all that richness. White wine can't handle this job.

option2Wine.feedbackText: Excellent! You've got it figured out. Bold meat needs bold wine. Cabernet's tannins and full body are exactly what ribeye calls for. Well done!
